001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.oklab;
002
003import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.FloatColors;
004import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.MathTools;
005import com.github.tommyettinger.ds.support.BitConversion;
006import com.github.tommyettinger.ds.support.EnhancedRandom;
007
008import java.util.Random;
009
010import static com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.oklab.Gamut.GAMUT_DATA;
011
012/**
013 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the Oklab color space.
014 * Oklab is a very new color space that builds on the same foundation as IPT, but seems to be better-calibrated for
015 * uniform lightness and colorfulness, instead of just the emphasis on uniform hue that IPT has. Relative to IPT, Oklab
016 * has a noticeably smaller range in chromatic channels (IPT's protan and tritan can range past 0.8 or as low as 0.35,
017 * but the similar A and B channels in Oklab don't stray past about 0.65 at the upper end, if that), but it does this so
018 * the difference between two Oklab colors is just the Euclidean distance between their components. A slight difference
019 * between Oklab and IPT here is that IPT shrinks the chromatic channels to store their -1 to 1 range in a color float's
020 * 0 to 1 range, then offsets the shrunken range from -0.5 to 0.5, to 0 to 1; Oklab does not need to shrink the range,
021 * and only offsets it in the same way (both just add 0.5).
022 * <br>
023 * Here's <a href="https://bottosson.github.io/posts/oklab/">Bj√∂rn Ottosson's original post introducing Oklab</a>.
024 * So far, <a href="https://raphlinus.github.io/color/2021/01/18/oklab-critique.html">it stood up to analysis by Raph
025 * Levien</a>, and seems to be gaining fans quickly.
026 */
027public class ColorTools {
028        /**
029         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, L (luminance or lightness), A
030         * (a chromatic component ranging from greenish to reddish, called protan in IPT), B (a chromatic component ranging
031         * from bluish to yellowish, called tritan in IPT), and alpha (or opacity). L should be
032         * between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very light
033         * colors (almost only white). A and B range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5.
034         * There's some aesthetic value in changing just one chroma value. When A is high and B is low, the color is more
035         * purple/magenta, when both are low it is more bluish, when B is high and A is low, the color tends to be greenish,
036         * and when both are high it tends to be orange. When A and B are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.
037         * Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
038         * <br>
039         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as
040         * L, A, and B, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original L,
041         * A, and B values if the original values were in the range that {@link #channelL(float)}, {@link #channelA(float)},
042         * and {@link #channelB(float)} return. You can use {@link #inGamut(float, float, float)} to check if a given set of
043         * L, A, and B values is in-gamut, that is, it can be converted to and from an RGB color without going out of the
044         * valid range. If you just want to enforce that a color is in-gamut, you can use
045         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}, which takes the same parameters this method does, or
046         * {@link #limitToGamut(float)} if you already have a packed float color that could be out-of-gamut.
047         *
048         * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of Oklab, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
049         * @param a     0f to 1f, protan or A component of Oklab, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
050         * @param b     0f to 1f, tritan or B component of Oklab, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
051         * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
052         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
053         */
054        public static float oklab(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
055                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (b * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
056                                | ((int) (a * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (l * 255) & 0xFF));
057        }
058
059        /**
060         * An approximation of the cube-root function for float inputs and outputs.
061         * This can be about twice as fast as {@link Math#cbrt(double)}. This
062         * version does not tolerate negative inputs, because in the narrow use
063         * case it has in this class, it never is given negative inputs.
064         * <br>
065         * Has very low relative error (less than 1E-9) when inputs are uniformly
066         * distributed between 0 and 512, and absolute mean error of less than
067         * 1E-6 in the same scenario. Uses a bit-twiddling method similar to one
068         * presented in Hacker's Delight and also used in early 3D graphics (see
069         * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_inverse_square_root for more, but
070         * this code approximates cbrt(x) and not 1/sqrt(x)). This specific code
071         * was originally by Marc B. Reynolds, posted in his "Stand-alone-junk"
072         * repo: https://github.com/Marc-B-Reynolds/Stand-alone-junk/blob/master/src/Posts/ballcube.c#L182-L197 .
073         * It's worth noting that while hardware instructions for finding the
074         * square root of a float have gotten extremely fast, the same is not
075         * true for the cube root (which has to allow negative inputs), so while
076         * the bit-twiddling inverse square root is no longer a beneficial
077         * optimization on current hardware, this does seem to help.
078         * <br>
079         * This is used when converting from RGB to Oklab, as an intermediate step.
080         * @param x any non-negative finite float to find the cube root of
081         * @return the cube root of x, approximated
082         */
083        private static float cbrtPositive(float x) {
084                int ix = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(x);
085                final float x0 = x;
086                ix = (ix>>>2) + (ix>>>4);
087                ix += (ix>>>4);
088                ix += (ix>>>8) + 0x2A5137A0;
089                x  = BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(ix);
090                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
091                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
092                return x;
093        }
094
095        /**
096         * Used when converting from Oklab to RGB, as an intermediate step.
097         * Really just {@code x * x * x}.
098         * @param x one of the LMS Prime channels to be converted to LMS
099         * @return an LMS channel value, which can be converted to RGB
100         */
101        private static float cube(final float x) {
102                return x * x * x;
103        }
104
105        /**
106         * The same as floor() from libGDX's MathUtils class, this gets the int floor of a float between -16384 and 16384.
107         * @param f a float between -16384 and 16384
108         * @return the floor of f, as an int
109         */
110        private static int floor(final float f) {
111                return (int)(f + 0x1p14) - 0x4000;
112        }
113        /**
114         * Used when given non-linear sRGB inputs to make them linear, approximating with gamma 2.0.
115         * Really just {@code component * component}.
116         * @param component any non-linear channel of a color, to be made linear
117         * @return a linear version of component
118         */
119        private static float forwardGamma(final float component) {
120                return component * component;
121        }
122
123        /**
124         * Used to return from a linear, gamma-corrected input to an sRGB, non-linear output, using gamma 2.0.
125         * Really just gets the square root of component, as a float.
126         * @param component a linear channel of a color, to be made non-linear
127         * @return a non-linear version of component
128         */
129        private static float reverseGamma(final float component) {
130                return (float)Math.sqrt(component);
131        }
132
133        /**
134         * Changes the curve of a requested L value so that it matches the internally-used curve. This takes a curve with a
135         * very-dark area similar to sRGB (a very small one), and makes it significantly larger. This is typically used on
136         * "to Oklab" conversions.
137         * @param L lightness, from 0 to 1 inclusive
138         * @return an adjusted L value that can be used internally
139         */
140        public static float forwardLight(final float L) {
141                return (L - 1.004f) / (1f - L * 0.4285714f) + 1.004f;
142        }
143
144        /**
145         * Changes the curve of the internally-used lightness when it is output to another format. This makes the very-dark
146         * area smaller, matching (kind-of) the curve that the standard sRGB lightness uses. This is typically used on "from
147         * Oklab" conversions.
148         * @param L lightness, from 0 to 1 inclusive
149         * @return an adjusted L value that can be fed into a conversion to RGBA or something similar
150         */
151        public static float reverseLight(final float L) {
152                return (L - 0.993f) / (1f + L * 0.75f) + 0.993f;
153        }
154
155        /**
156         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
157         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
158         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
159         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
160         */
161        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
162        {
163                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
164                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
165                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
166                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
167                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
168                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
169                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
170                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
171                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
172                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
173                return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
174        }
175
176        /**
177         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
178         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
179         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
180         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
181         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
182         */
183        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
184        {
185                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
186                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
187                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
188                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
189                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
190                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
191                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
192                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
193                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
194                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
195                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
196        }
197
198        /**
199         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
200         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
201         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
202         */
203        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
204                final float r = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
205                final float g = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
206                final float b = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
207
208                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
209                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
210                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
211
212                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
213                                Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
214                                                (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
215                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
216                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
217                                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
218        }
219
220        /**
221         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
222         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
223         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
224         */
225        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
226                final int abgr = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
227                final float r = forwardGamma((abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
228                final float g = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
229                final float b = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
230                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
231                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
232                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
233                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
234                                Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
235                                                (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
236                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
237                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
238                                                | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
239        }
240
241        /**
242         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
243         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
244         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
245         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
246         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
247         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
248         */
249        public static float fromRGBA(float r, float g, float b, final float a) {
250                r = forwardGamma(r);
251                g = forwardGamma(g);
252                b = forwardGamma(b);
253                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
254                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
255                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
256                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
257                                Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
258                                                (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
259                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
260                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
261                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
262        }
263
264        /**
265         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
266         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
267         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
268         */
269        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
270        {
271                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
272                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
273                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
274                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
275                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
276                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
277                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
278                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
279        }
280
281        /**
282         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
283         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
284         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
285         */
286        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
287        {
288                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
289                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
290                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
291                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
292                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
293                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
294                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
295                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
296        }
297
298        /**
299         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
300         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
301         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
302         */
303        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
304        {
305                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
306                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
307                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
308                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
309                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
310                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
311                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
312                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
313        }
314
315        /**
316         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
317         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
318         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
319         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
320         */
321        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
322        {
323                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
324        }
325
326        /**
327         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
328         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
329         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
330         */
331        public static float red(final float encoded)
332        {
333                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
334                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
335                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
336                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
337                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
338                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
339                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
340                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
341        }
342
343        /**
344         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
345         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
346         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
347         */
348        public static float green(final float encoded)
349        {
350                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
351                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
352                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
353                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
354                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
355                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
356                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
357                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
358        }
359
360        /**
361         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
362         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
363         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
364         */
365        public static float blue(final float encoded)
366        {
367                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
368                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
369                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
370                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
371                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
372                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
373                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
374                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
375        }
376
377        /**
378         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
379         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
380         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
381         */
382        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
383        {
384                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
385        }
386
387        /**
388         * Gets the "chroma" or "colorfulness" of a given Oklab color. Chroma is similar to saturation in that grayscale
389         * values have 0 saturation and 0 chroma, while brighter colors have high saturation and chroma. The difference is
390         * that colors that are perceptually more-colorful have higher chroma than colors that are perceptually
391         * less-colorful, regardless of hue, whereas saturation changes its meaning depending on the hue and lightness. That
392         * is, the most saturated color for a given hue and lightness always has a saturation of 1, but if that color
393         * isn't perceptually very colorful (as is the case for very dark and very light colors), it will have a chroma that
394         * is much lower than the maximum. The result of this method can't be negative, grayscale values have very close to
395         * 0 chroma, and the most colorful values (close to cyan) should have 0.334f chroma.
396         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
397         * @return a float between 0.0f and 0.334f that represents how colorful the given value is
398         */
399        public static float chroma(final float encoded) {
400                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
401                final float a = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1FE) - 0xFF)  * 0x1p-8f;
402                final float b = ((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1FE) - 0xFF) * 0x1p-8f;
403                return (float) Math.sqrt(a * a + b * b);
404        }
405
406        /**
407         * Given a hue and lightness, this gets the (approximate) maximum chroma possible for that hue-lightness
408         * combination. This is useful to know the bounds of {@link #chroma(float)}. This should be no greater
409         * than 0.334f .
410         * @param hue the hue, typically between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
411         * @param lightness the lightness, clamped between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
412         * @return the maximum possible chroma for the given hue and lightness, between 0.0f and 0.334f
413         */
414        public static float chromaLimit(final float hue, final float lightness){
415                final int idx = (int) (Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f) * 255.999f) << 8
416                                | (int) (256f * (hue - floor(hue)));
417                return (GAMUT_DATA[idx] + 1.5f) * 0x1p-8f;
418        }
419
420        /**
421         * Gets a color as an Oklab packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
422         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
423         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
424         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
425         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
426         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
427         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
428         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
429         * <br>
430         * This method considers its hue, saturation, and lightness parameters as the HSL color space does. You may instead
431         * want the method {@link #oklabByHSL(float, float, float, float)}, which treats lightness exactly as Oklab does,
432         * and handles hue and saturation with the Oklab color solid (which is shaped oddly) instead of the HSL color solid
433         * (which is a bicone, with a wide cone pointing up attached at the base to another wide cone pointing down).
434         * Using oklabByHSL() should be faster in many cases, and the lightness handling alone may be a reason to use it.
435         * There is also {@link #oklabByHCL(float, float, float, float)}, which may be preferable if you want a specific
436         * amount of chroma (colorful-ness) and no greater.
437         *
438         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
439         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
440         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
441         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
442         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
443         */
444        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
445                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
446                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
447                } else {
448                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
449                }
450        }
451
452        /**
453         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color as HSL would calculate it, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f,
454         * inclusive. This is different from {@link #chroma(float)}; see that method's documentation for details. It is also
455         * different from {@link #oklabSaturation(float)}, which gets the saturation as Oklab understands it rather than how
456         * HSL understands it.
457         *
458         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
459         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
460         */
461        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
462                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
463                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
464                if(Math.abs(L - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
465                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
466                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
467                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
468                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
469                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
470                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
471                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
472                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
473                float x, y, w;
474                if(g < b) {
475                        x = b;
476                        y = g;
477                }
478                else {
479                        x = g;
480                        y = b;
481                }
482                if(r < x) {
483                        w = r;
484                }
485                else {
486                        w = x;
487                        x = r;
488                }
489                return x - Math.min(w, y);
490        }
491
492        /**
493         * Defined as per HSL; normally you only need {@link #channelL(float)} to get accurate lightness for Oklab. You can
494         * also use {@link #oklabLightness(float)}, which is an alias for channelL(). This ranges from 0.0f (black) to 1.0f
495         * (white).
496         *
497         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
498         * @return the lightness of the given color as HSL would calculate it
499         */
500        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
501                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
502                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
503                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
504                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
505                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
506                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
507                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
508                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
509                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
510                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
511                float x, y, w;
512                if(g < b) {
513                        x = b;
514                        y = g;
515                }
516                else {
517                        x = g;
518                        y = b;
519                }
520                if(r < x) {
521                        w = r;
522                }
523                else {
524                        w = x;
525                        x = r;
526                }
527                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
528                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
529        }
530
531        /**
532         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
533         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased). You can also use {@link #oklabHue(float)}, which
534         * positions the different hues at different values, somewhat, from this, but is more accurate to how Oklab handles
535         * hues.
536         *
537         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
538         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
539         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
540         */
541        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
542                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
543                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
544                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
545                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
546                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
547                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
548                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
549                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
550                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
551                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
552                float x, y, z, w;
553                if(g < b) {
554                        x = b;
555                        y = g;
556                        z = -1f;
557                        w = 2f / 3f;
558                }
559                else {
560                        x = g;
561                        y = b;
562                        z = 0f;
563                        w = -1f / 3f;
564                }
565                if(r < x) {
566                        z = w;
567                        w = r;
568                }
569                else {
570                        w = x;
571                        x = r;
572                }
573                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
574                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
575        }
576
577        /**
578         * The "L" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
579         * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
580         *
581         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
582         * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
583         */
584        public static float channelL(final float encoded)
585        {
586                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
587        }
588
589        /**
590         * The "A" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the B channel describes the
591         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If A is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
592         * blue; if A is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the A of a color with
593         * {@link #raiseA(float, float)} and {@link #lowerA(float, float)}.
594         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
595         * @return the A value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
596         */
597        public static float channelA(final float encoded)
598        {
599                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
600        }
601
602        /**
603         * The "B" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the A channel describes the
604         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If B is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
605         * blue or purple; if B is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
606         * the B of a color with {@link #raiseB(float, float)} and {@link #lowerB(float, float)}.
607         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
608         * @return the B value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
609         */
610        public static float channelB(final float encoded)
611        {
612                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
613        }
614
615        /**
616         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
617         * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not Oklab! Takes
618         * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
619         * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color. The float is
620         * likely to be different than the result of {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation,
621         * lightness, and opacity are all 0. This won't allocate any objects.
622         * <br>
623         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
624         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
625         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
626         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
627         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
628         * <br>
629         * You may want {@link #editOklab(float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float)} instead, which
630         * adjusts the L, A, B, and alpha channels directly instead of converting to HSL and back.
631         *
632         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
633         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
634         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
635         * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
636         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
637         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
638         */
639        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
640                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
641                final float L = Math.min(Math.max(light + reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f), 0f), 1f);
642                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (decoded >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f), 1f);
643                if (L <= 0.001f)
644                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
645                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
646                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
647                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
648                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
649                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
650                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
651                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
652                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
653                float x, y, z, w;
654                if(g < b) {
655                        x = b;
656                        y = g;
657                        z = -1f;
658                        w = 2f / 3f;
659                }
660                else {
661                        x = g;
662                        y = b;
663                        z = 0f;
664                        w = -1f / 3f;
665                }
666                if(r < x) {
667                        z = w;
668                        w = r;
669                }
670                else {
671                        w = x;
672                        x = r;
673                }
674                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
675                final float lum = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
676                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
677                saturation += (x - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
678                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
679        }
680
681        /**
682         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
683         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
684         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
685         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
686         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
687         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
688         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
689         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
690         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
691         */
692        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
693                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
694                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
695        }
696
697        /**
698         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
699         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
700         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
701         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
702         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
703         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
704         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
705         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
706         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
707         */
708        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
709                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
710                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
711        }
712
713        /**
714         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
715         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
716         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
717         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
718         * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
719         * alpha and L of start as-is.
720         * @see #lowerA(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
721         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
722         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
723         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
724         */
725        public static float raiseA(final float start, final float change) {
726                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
727                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
728        }
729
730        /**
731         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
732         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
733         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
734         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
735         * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
736         * L of start as-is.
737         * @see #raiseA(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
738         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
739         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
740         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
741         */
742        public static float lowerA(final float start, final float change) {
743                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
744                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
745        }
746
747        /**
748         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
749         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed color, as
750         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
751         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
752         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
753         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
754         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
755         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
756         * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
757         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
758         */
759        public static float raiseB(final float start, final float change) {
760                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
761                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
762        }
763
764        /**
765         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
766         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed color, as
767         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
768         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
769         * towards a more artificial color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
770         * alpha and L of start as-is.
771         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
772         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
773         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
774         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
775         */
776        public static float lowerB(final float start, final float change) {
777                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
778                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
779        }
780
781        /**
782         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
783         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
784         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
785         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
786         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
787         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
788         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
789         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
790         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
791         */
792        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
793                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
794                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
795        }
796
797        /**
798         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
799         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
800         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
801         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
802         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
803         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
804         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
805         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
806         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
807         */
808        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
809                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
810                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
811        }
812
813        /**
814         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
815         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
816         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes A and B; it leaves L and alpha alone, unlike
817         * {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes L.
818         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
819         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
820         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
821         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
822         */
823        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
824                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
825                return oklab((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
826                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
827                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
828                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
829        }
830
831        /**
832         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
833         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
834         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This changes only A and B. Higher values for {@code change} can
835         * force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}.
836         * The alpha never changes.
837         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
838         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
839         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
840         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
841         */
842        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
843                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
844                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
845                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
846                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
847                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
848        }
849
850        /**
851         * Given a packed float Oklab color {@code mainColor} and another Oklab color that it should be made to contrast with,
852         * gets a packed float Oklab color with roughly inverted L but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B
853         * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
854         * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for L values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
855         * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
856         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the L unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
857         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
858         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
859         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
860         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
861         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
862         *                     this is the color that will be adjusted
863         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
864         *                            the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
865         * @return a different Oklab packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
866         */
867        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
868        {
869                final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
870                                contrastBits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
871                                L = (bits & 0xff),
872                                A = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
873                                B = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
874                                cL = (contrastBits & 0xff),
875                                cA = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
876                                cB = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
877                if((A - cA) * (A - cA) + (B - cB) * (B - cB) >= 0x10000)
878                        return mainColor;
879                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((bits & 0xFEFFFF00) | (int) (cL < 128 ? L * 0.45f + 140 : 127 - L * 0.45f));
880        }
881
882        /**
883         * Given a packed float Oklab color {@code mainColor} and another Oklab color that it should be made to contrast
884         * with, gets a packed float Oklab color with L that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s L,
885         * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
886         * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
887         * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
888         * <br>
889         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
890         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
891         * averages the original L of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
892         * @param mainColor a packed Oklab float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
893         * @param contrastingColor a packed Oklab float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the L of this
894         * @return a different packed Oklab float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
895         */
896        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
897        {
898                final int main = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
899                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
900        }
901
902        /**
903         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's L and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
904         * with the original L. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
905         * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
906         * @param mainColor a packed Oklab float color
907         * @return a different packed Oklab float color, with its L channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
908         */
909        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
910                final int oklab = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
911                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((oklab & 0xFEFFFF00) | (oklab + 128 & 0xFF) + (oklab & 0xFF) >>> 1));
912        }
913
914        /**
915         * Makes the additive Oklab color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
916         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
917         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
918         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
919         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
920         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
921         * @return an Oklab float color between gray and {@code color}
922         */
923        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
924                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color),
925                                sL = 0x80, sA = 0x80, sB = 0x80, sAlpha = 0xFE,
926                                eL = (e & 0xFF), eA = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eB = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
927                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF)
928                                | (((int) (sA + fraction * (eA - sA)) & 0xFF) << 8)
929                                | (((int) (sB + fraction * (eB - sB)) & 0xFF) << 16)
930                                | (((int) (sAlpha + fraction * (eAlpha - sAlpha)) & 0xFE) << 24));
931        }
932
933        /**
934         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
935         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
936         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
937         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
938         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the L, A, and B of the
939         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
940         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers A and B extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while L goes from 0 to 1,
941         * but only internally for measuring distance).
942         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
943         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
944         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
945         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
946         */
947        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
948                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color);
949                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
950                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
951                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
952                final float limit = variance * variance;
953                float dist, x, y, z;
954                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
955                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
956                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
957                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
958                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
959                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
960                        if(dist <= limit && inGamut(x += L, y = (A + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, z = (B + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f))
961                                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
962                                                | ((int)(y * 255.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.5f));
963                }
964                return color;
965        }
966
967        /**
968         * Given a 1D int index between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive), this treats the 1D index as two parts (lightness and
969         * hue angle, both from 0 to 255) and gets the distance from grayscale to the edge of the gamut at that lightness
970         * and hue. The index can be constructed from a lightness value {@code L} from 0 to 255, and a hue value {@code H}
971         * from 0 to 255 with: {@code (L << 8 | H)} or the simpler equivalent {@code (L * 256 + H)}. These assume L and H
972         * have been limited to the 0 to 255 range already. This does not bounds-check index. Because hue is not typically
973         * measured between 0 and 255, getting that value is a bit different; you can use
974         * {@link MathTools#atan2_(float, float)} (with an Oklab color's B for y, then its A for x) and multiply it by 256
975         * to get H.
976         * <br>
977         * The distance this returns is a byte between 0 and 84 (both inclusive), as the Euclidean distance from the center
978         * grayscale value at the lightness in the index, to the edge of the gamut at the same lightness, along the hue in
979         * the index. This is measured in a space from -1 to 1 for both A and B, with the 0 in the center meaning grayscale,
980         * and multiplied by 256 to get a meaningful byte value. To return to the A and B values Oklab uses here, you would
981         * need to use some trigonometry on the hue (if it's in the 0 to 1 range, you can call
982         * {@link MathTools#cos_(float)} on the hue to almost get A, and {@link MathTools#sin_(float)} to almost get B),
983         * then multiply each of those by the distance, divide each by 256.0, and add 0.5.
984         * <br>
985         * Only intended for the narrow cases where external code needs read-only access to the internal Oklab gamut data.
986         * The gamut data is quite large (it is in a 71 KB source file containing only the gamut, while the entire IPT_HQ
987         * ColorTools file is 56 KB, and includes everything else except a gamut table), so it's better to have
988         * direct read access to it without being able to accidentally rewrite it.
989         * @param index must be between 0 and 65535; the upper 8 bits are lightness and the lower 8 are hue angle.
990         * @return a byte (always between 0 and 84, inclusive) representing the Euclidean distance between a grayscale value and the most saturated value possible, using the above measurements
991         */
992        public static byte getRawGamutValue(int index){
993                return GAMUT_DATA[index];
994        }
995
996        /**
997         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as Oklab, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
998         * @param packed a packed float color as Oklab
999         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1000         */
1001        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
1002        {
1003                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1004                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 255f;
1005                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127f) / 255f;
1006                final float g = GAMUT_DATA[(decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int)(256f * MathTools.atan2_(B, A))];
1007                return g * g * 0x1p-18 + 0x1p-14 >= (A * A + B * B);
1008        }
1009
1010        /**
1011         * Returns true if the given Oklab values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1012         * @param L lightness channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1013         * @param A green-to-red chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1014         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1015         * @return true if the given Oklab channels can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1016         */
1017        public static boolean inGamut(float L, float A, float B)
1018        {
1019                A = ((int) (A * 255) - 127f) / 255f;
1020                B = ((int) (B * 255) - 127f) / 255f;
1021                final float g = GAMUT_DATA[((int) (L * 255) & 0xFF) << 8 | (int)(256f * MathTools.atan2_(B, A))];
1022                return g * g * 0x1p-18 + 0x1p-14 >= (A * A + B * B);
1023
1024                ////This was the old code for this inGamut(), which was subtly different from the other inGamut() when called
1025                /// on a packed float. The packed floats can go ever-so-slightly towards or away from the edge.
1026//              A = (A - 0.5f);
1027//              B = (B - 0.5f);
1028//              final byte g = GAMUT_DATA[((int)(L * 255.999f) << 8) | (int)(256f * MathTools.atan2_(B, A))];
1029//              return g * g * 0x1p-16 >= (A * A + B * B);
1030
1031        }
1032
1033        /**
1034         * Gets the color with the same L as the Oklab color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
1035         * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
1036         * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
1037         * @param packed a packed float color in Oklab format; does not need to be in-gamut
1038         * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
1039         * @see #limitToGamut(float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation for out-of-gamut colors.
1040         */
1041        public static float maximizeSaturation(final float packed) {
1042                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1043                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1044                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1045                final float hue = MathTools.atan2_(B, A);
1046                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1047                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1048                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1049                                (decoded & 0xFE0000FF) |
1050                                                (int) (MathTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1051                                                (int) (MathTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16);
1052        }
1053        /**
1054         * Gets the color with the same L as the Oklab color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
1055         * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
1056         * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
1057         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1058         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1059         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1060         * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1061         * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
1062         * @see #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation
1063         * for out-of-gamut colors.
1064         */
1065        public static float maximizeSaturation(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1066                L = Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f);
1067                A = Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f;
1068                B = Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f;
1069                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1070                final float hue = MathTools.atan2_(B, A);
1071                final int idx = (int) (L * 255.999f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1072                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1073                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1074                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1075                                                (int) (MathTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16 |
1076                                                (int) (MathTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1077                                                (int) (L * 255.999f));
1078        }
1079
1080        /**
1081         * Gets the hue of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands hue rather than how HSL does.
1082         * This is different from {@link #hue(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
1083         * and 1 (exclusive).
1084         *
1085         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1086         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive) that represents hue in the Oklab color space
1087         */
1088        public static float oklabHue(final float packed) {
1089                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1090                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1091                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1092                return MathTools.atan2_(B, A);
1093        }
1094
1095        /**
1096         * Gets the saturation of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands saturation rather than how HSL does.
1097         * Saturation here is a fraction of the chroma limit (see {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}) for a given hue and
1098         * lightness, and is between 0 and 1 almost all the time. Saturation should always be a float between 0 (inclusive)
1099         * and 1 (inclusive).
1100         *
1101         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1102         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents saturation in the Oklab color space
1103         */
1104        public static float oklabSaturation(final float packed) {
1105                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1106                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1107                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1108                final float hue = MathTools.atan2_(B, A);
1109                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1110                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] + 1.5f;
1111                return dist == 3.5f ? 0f : (A * A + B * B) * 4f / (dist * dist);
1112        }
1113        /**
1114         * Gets the lightness of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands lightness rather than how HSL does.
