1115         * This is different from {@link #lightness(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
1116         * and 1 (inclusive).
1117         * <br>
1118         * This is the same as {@link #channelL(float)}.
1119         *
1120         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1121         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents lightness in the Oklab color space
1122         */
1123        public static float oklabLightness(final float packed){
1124                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed) & 0xff) / 255f;
1125        }
1126
1127        /**
1128         * A different way to specify an Oklab color, using hue, saturation, lightness, and alpha like a normal HSL(A) color
1129         * but calculating them directly in the Oklab color space. This is more efficient than
1130         * {@link #floatGetHSL(float, float, float, float)}, but for colors with less than 0.5f lightness, it can be very
1131         * unpredictable in how it handles saturation. Most colors between 0.5 and 0.75 hue that also have less than 0.5
1132         * lightness are extremely desaturated and close to gray, regardless of what you give for saturation, and these
1133         * colors suddenly jump to very saturated around 0.75 hue and higher. To avoid this issue, you may prefer using
1134         * {@link #oklabByHCL(float, float, float, float)}, which takes an absolute chroma as opposed to the saturation here
1135         * (which is a fraction of the maximum chroma).
1136         * <br>
1137         * Note that this takes a different value for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just
1138         * like its {@code saturation} and the method {@link #saturation(float)}, and {@code lightness} and the method
1139         * {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent to
1140         * {@link #channelL(float)}, but the saturation here refers to what fraction the chroma should be of the maximum
1141         * chroma for the given hue and lightness. You can use {@link #oklabHue(float)}, {@link #oklabSaturation(float)},
1142         * and {@link #oklabLightness(float)} to get the hue, saturation, and lightness values from an existing color that
1143         * this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too).
1144         * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
1145         * @param saturation will be clamped between 0 and 1
1146         * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
1147         * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
1148         * @return a packed Oklab float color that tries to match the requested hue, saturation, and lightness
1149         */
1150        public static float oklabByHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float alpha) {
1151                lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
1152                saturation = Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f);
1153                hue -= floor(hue);
1154                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1155                final int idx = (int) (lightness * 255.999f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1156                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * saturation * 0.5f;
1157                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1158                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1159                                                (int) (MathTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16 |
1160                                                (int) (MathTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1161                                                (int) (lightness * 255.999f));
1162        }
1163
1164        /**
1165         * A different way to specify an Oklab color, using hue, chroma, lightness, and alpha something like a normal HSL(A)
1166         * color but calculating them directly in the Oklab color space. This has you specify the desired chroma directly,
1167         * as obtainable with {@link #chroma(float)}, rather than the saturation, which is a fraction of the maximum chroma
1168         * (saturation is what {@link #oklabByHSL(float, float, float, float)} uses). Note that this takes a different value
1169         * for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just like {@code lightness} and the method
1170         * {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent to
1171         * {@link #channelL(float)}. If you use this to get two colors with the same chroma and lightness, but different
1172         * hue, then the resulting colors should have similar colorfulness unless one or both chroma values exceeded the
1173         * gamut limit (you can get this limit with {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}). If a chroma value given is greater
1174         * than the chroma limit, this clamps chroma to that limit. You can use {@link #oklabHue(float)},
1175         * {@link #chroma(float)}, and {@link #oklabLightness(float)} to get the hue, chroma, and lightness values from an
1176         * existing color that this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too).
1177         * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
1178         * @param chroma will be clamped between 0 and the maximum chroma possible for the given hue and lightness
1179         * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
1180         * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
1181         * @return a packed Oklab float color that tries to match the requested hue, chroma, and lightness
1182         */
1183        public static float oklabByHCL(float hue, float chroma, float lightness, float alpha) {
1184                lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
1185                chroma = Math.max(chroma, 0f);
1186                hue -= floor(hue);
1187                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1188                final int idx = (int) (lightness * 255.999f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1189                final float dist = Math.min(chroma * 127.5f, GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f);
1190                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1191                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1192                                                (int) (MathTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16 |
1193                                                (int) (MathTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1194                                                (int) (lightness * 255.999f));
1195        }
1196
1197        /**
1198         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1199         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is.
1200         * @param packed a packed float color in Oklab format; often this color is not in-gamut
1201         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1202         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1203         */
1204        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
1205                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1206                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1207                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1208                final float hue = MathTools.atan2_(B, A);
1209                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1210                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1211                if (dist * dist * 0.25f >= (A * A + B * B))
1212                        return packed;
1213                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1214                                (decoded & 0xFE0000FF) |
1215                                                (int) (MathTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1216                                                (int) (MathTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16);
1217        }
1218
1219        /**
1220         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1221         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is. This always produces
1222         * an opaque color.
1223         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1224         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1225         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1226         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1227         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1228         */
1229        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B) {
1230                return limitToGamut(L, A, B, 1f);
1231        }
1232        /**
1233         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1234         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is.
1235         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1236         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1237         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1238         * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1239         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1240         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1241         */
1242        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1243                L = Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f);
1244                A = Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f);
1245                B = Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f);
1246                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1247                final float A2 = (A - 0.5f);
1248                final float B2 = (B - 0.5f);
1249                final float hue = MathTools.atan2_(B2, A2);
1250                final int idx = (int) (L * 255.999f) << 8 | (int)(256f * hue);
1251                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1252                if(dist * dist * 0x1p-16f + 0x1p-14f >= (A2 * A2 + B2 * B2))
1253                        return oklab(L, A, B, alpha);
1254                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1255                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1256                                                (int) (MathTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16 |
1257                                                (int) (MathTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1258                                                (int) (L * 255.999f));
1259        }
1260
1261        /**
1262         * Given a packed float Oklab color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by adding the corresponding "add"
1263         * parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
1264         * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. This clamps the
1265         * resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
1266         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
1267         * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1268         * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1269         * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1270         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1271         * @return a packed float Oklab color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1272         */
1273        public static float editOklab(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha) {
1274                return editOklab(encoded, addL, addA, addB, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
1275        }
1276        /**
1277         * Given a packed float Oklab color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by first multiplying each channel by
1278         * the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping. This means
1279         * the lightness value {@code L} is multiplied by {@code mulL}, then has {@code addL} added, and then is clamped to
1280         * the normal range for L (0 to 1). This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
1281         * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged, or a value of 1 for any
1282         * "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. Note that this manipulates A and B in the -0.5 to 0.5 range, so if you
1283         * multiply by a small number like {@code 0.25f}, then this will produce a less-saturated color, and if you multiply
1284         * by a larger number like {@code 4f}, then you will get a much more-saturated color. This clamps the resulting
1285         * color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
1286         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
1287         * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1288         * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1289         * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1290         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1291         * @param mulL how much to multiply the L channel by; should be non-negative
1292         * @param mulA how much to multiply the A channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1293         * @param mulB how much to multiply the B channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1294         * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
1295         * @return a packed float Oklab color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1296         */
1297        public static float editOklab(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha,
1298                                                                  float mulL, float mulA, float mulB, float mulAlpha) {
1299                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1300                float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1301                float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
1302                float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
1303                float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
1304
1305                L = Math.min(Math.max(L * mulL + addL, 0f), 1f);
1306                A = Math.min(Math.max(A * mulA + addA * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
1307                B = Math.min(Math.max(B * mulB + addB * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
1308                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
1309                final float hue = MathTools.atan2_(B, A);
1310                final int idx = (int) (L * 255.999f) << 8 | (int)(256f * hue);
1311                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1312                if(dist * dist * 0x1p-16f >= (A * A + B * B))
1313                        return oklab(L, A + 0.5f, B + 0.5f, alpha);
1314                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1315                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1316                                                (int) (MathTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16 |
1317                                                (int) (MathTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1318                                                (int) (L * 255.999f));
1319        }
1320
1321        /**
1322         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1323         * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like
1324         * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.ds.support.LaserRandom})
1325         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1326         */
1327        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1328                float L = random.nextFloat();
1329                float A = random.nextFloat();
1330                float B = random.nextFloat();
1331                while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
1332                        L = random.nextFloat();
1333                        A = random.nextFloat();
1334                        B = random.nextFloat();
1335                }
1336                return oklab(L, A, B, 1f);
1337        }
1338
1339        /**
1340         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1341         * This is named differently from {@link #randomColor(Random)} to avoid confusion when a class both extends Random
1342         * and implements EnhancedRandom.
1343         * @param random any implementation of jdkgdxds' EnhancedRandom, such as a
1344         * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.ds.support.DistinctRandom} or
1345         * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.ds.support.FourWheelRandom}
1346         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1347         */
1348        public static float randomizedColor(EnhancedRandom random) {
1349                float L = random.nextExclusiveFloat();
1350                float A = random.nextExclusiveFloat();
1351                float B = random.nextExclusiveFloat();
1352                while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
1353                        L = random.nextExclusiveFloat();
1354                        A = random.nextExclusiveFloat();
1355                        B = random.nextExclusiveFloat();
1356                }
1357                return oklab(L, A, B, 1f);
1358        }
1359}
